title: Research
text:
Micro-projections of multidimensional child poverty in sub-Saharan Africa 
            
            
                Marina Vicini, John Fitzgerald, Daniela Pinto Veizaga,  Arpita Saggar, Oliver Fiala Â

                XAI-MethylMarker: Explainable AI approach for biomarker discovery for breast cancer subtype classification using methylation data

                Expert Systems with Applications (2023)

                Explainable AI-based biomarker discovery framework applied to DNA methylation data to determine a small biomarker set for breast cancer stratification.

School of Computer Science, University of Leeds Oct 2023 â€“ Present

COMP5122M Data Science  Module Lead: Dr Duygu Sarikaya
COMP2121 Data Mining  Module Lead: Prof Eric Atwell
COMP5840M Data Mining and Text Analytics  Module Lead: Prof Eric Atwell
COMP2611 Artificial Intelligence  Module Lead: Dr Brandon Bennett




Data Study Group, Alan Turing Institute Dec 2023 â€“ Dec 2023
A short research project in collaboration with the UK Centre for Ecology & Hydrology to apply machine learning for biodiversity monitoring. REPORT

Developed methods for analysing how variations in weather (temperature, rainfall, sunshine and wind) affect species abundance for moth populations.
Produced interactive data visualisations showing spatial distributions of different species to promote stakeholder engagement and interest in biodiversity monitoring.




Data Science for Social Good Foundation and University of Warwick Jun 2022 â€“ Aug 2022
A joint project with UNICEF and Save the Children. The aim was to predict multi-dimensional child poverty in Sub-Saharan Africa to optimise resource allocation.

A Python package to produce high-resolution poverty estimates using data from Google Earth Engine, Facebookâ€™s ads connectivity graph and Relative Wealth Index, and open telecommunications tower networks. Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) to ground predictions of the machine learning model(s).
Led the development of an autoencoder-based feature extractor for GEE rasters and produced uncertainity estimates for the model(s) using conformal prediction.
Results presented at the UN World Data Forum 2023 and published as a chapter in the Handbook on Child Poverty and Inequality.






Languages: Python, R, C++, SQL, HTML/CSS, JavaScript, LaTeX.
Frameworks & Tools: Git, Slurm, Tensorflow, PyTorch, Keras, Transformers, Scikit-Learn, Streamlit, Quarto.

title: About
text: My research interests span generative AI, human-computer interaction, and AI-enhanced learning. Iâ€™m interested in investigating methods to improve the realism of foundation models, and combining these models across different modalities to produce interactive simulacra of human behaviour. My doctoral research falls within the AI Research Theme and Iâ€™m part of the MIRAI (Medical Imaging and GeneRative AI) and AI4L (AI for Languages) Research Groups at the University of Leeds.

title: About
text:
Other Activities
I am involved in relevant activites beyond my research. Iâ€™m a student organiser for our CDTâ€™s annual conference in June 2025. I was part of the organising team in 2024 as well, and moderated the industry panel at the event. Iâ€™ve also been involved in STEM engagement through the Iâ€™m a Scientist, Get me out of here programme. During my masterâ€™s, I edited the universityâ€™s annual tech magazine, Srijan, and volunteered as a Python programming mentor at the Uplift Project by GirlScript Foundation.
Outside of academic life, I enjoy listening to music, swimming, playing chess and badminton, roller skating and bowling (though Iâ€™m not very good at it ðŸ˜…). Below are some pictures of my PhD journey so far.

title: Arpita Saggar
text:
Hello!
Iâ€™m a PhD student within the UKRI CDT in AI for Medical Diagnosis and Care at the University of Leeds. My research focuses on using generative AI to create patient simulations for medical training. Iâ€™m fortunate to be supervised by Professor David Hogg, Dr Duygu Sarikaya, Dr Jonathan Darling and Professor Vania Dimitrova.
Before starting my PhD, I was a Data Science for Social Good fellow at the University of Warwick, where I worked with Save The Children UK and UNICEF to map child poverty across sub-Saharan Africa. My background is in Computing, and Iâ€™ve previously worked on research projects at the intersection of AI and healthcare.
